ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned the characteristics of the far-right in a variety of cultural and historical contexts.
how to debate

We learned about various far-right groups and movements in Europe, the United States, and elsewhere, discussing these from a variety of perspectives and narratives (ranging from World War II to the present).
I learned a great deal about the far-right in the United States and in Europe. Although the class was not limited to just these two regions, it was definitely focused on these regions.
I really feel like this course left me more confident in my ability to write for political science and talk about the radical right.
Learned about the history and the development of the far-right in the US and Europe (mostly). Talked about how people come to the far-right and how movements build strength.
Absolutely stunned by this course. My most challenging and intellectually stimulating course I have taken in my time at Yale.

In this course I learned about extreme- and radical-right movements, both through case studies as well as theoretical approaches. We looked at both historical examples as well as modern ones. After this course I have greater insight about the motives that drive an individual to join a far-right movement, as well as how far-right groups engage in a society as a whole.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The readings were not very interesting in the beginning of the course. They focused, maybe a little too much, on the American historical context.
Strengths: Paris was great, discussion is lively, readings and assignments were interesting. Really appreciated the videos that were integrated into discussion as well.

I really would love it if the course talked about radical right movements in non-white contexts; whether in Africa or South America, or as a minority of racial supremacy groups (Black Trumpites) or Nation of Islam.

Strength: Professor Aslanidis is incredibly passionate and is a really wonderful professor. The assigned readings were one of the best parts of the course, and seminar was always engaging. He often paired videos and clips with what we are discussing that day.

Weaknesses: The only weakness I could think of (although some people might see this as a positive) is that assignments are graded from 1-10 on a kind of arbitrary scale since there was no rubric provided. Some of the formatting requirements for the papers were also a bit odd, but both of these are really small issues. The seminar is still wonderful and I highly suggest it!

The strengths: organization, work load, and professor 
Weaknesses: Class Engagement

Great readings, great professor, interesting course material. Workload every week was very manageable, and the readings were fascinating. Class discussions were always interesting, thanks to Prof. Aslanidis leading discussions but also engaged peers. Weakness: sometimes class discussions got too heated and personal, and the Zoom chat did us no favors.

Strengths: interesting readings. Professor Aslanidis is very engaging and has good insight into the topic. Meet with him before you write papers and he'll really help you dig deeper. The class is a nice mix of hard polisci and history. 
Weaknesses: Class discussion was a mess. This was more due to the makeup of our class, but things got very heated and it was hard to de-escalate over Zoom. Coming to class felt very stressful at times due to section bullies.
Professor Paris is the biggest strength of the course. Thank you for balancing the discussions with documentaries and great reading material. Wish this could be in-person.

One strength of the course is its structure. I thought that the week-by-week subject matter flowed well and provided a comprehensive understanding to the overall themes of the course. In addition, the larger writing assignments were spaced out enough to be manageable. 
One point of caution in this course (and in this semester I viewed as a weakness) is the quality of the discussion is largely dependent on the students and their background knowledge that they bring to the course. This means that there can be a lot of academic jargon or abstract topics that can alienate others  in the seminar who aren't familiar with it. In our seminar I frequently felt that class was a hostile space where there was one right answer to the discussion and as a result, discussing the nuances of certain topics was cast aside because there were too many minefields.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof. Aslanidis was great with adjustment to pandemic learning.
Virtual seminars are always be difficult, though I thought this one was actually rather effective in including all students in class.
Since it was a once a week seminar, there was not much that needed to change for virtual learning. There were no prerecorded lectures or anything like that.

The chat was awful in this class. It ran parallel to the class discussion, and people would have to defend their points they made verbally in the chat or else they would be attacked. The chat should have been turned off.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes.

Absolutely. The topic is itself incredibly interesting, especially when discussed from the perspective of such a variety of literature and documentaries. Paris himself is fantastic: energetic, passionate, knowledgeable, and dedicated to his students' success. Assignments are straightforward yet thought-provoking.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. If you are remotely interested in the far-right, especially in an American or a European context, you should take this class! Professor Aslanidis is great, and the course is structured so well.
Yes, the professor and the course are incredible!
Yes!
I would. It's very topical and will continue to be that way. It gives you some great talking points about the far right, and the final paper allows you to explore any topic related to the movement.
Absolutely YES
Yes! Great professor and great class conversations.
I would recommend this course to another student if they have an interest in both modern and historical politics and political theory.
